abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about the
            institutional development of municipal solid waste sector in
            Morocco. Out of a total Moroccan population of 30 million,
            18 million lived in urban areas. Moroccan cities are
            characterized by high population densities and rapid growth.
            These cities suffered from several forms of environmental
            degradation, including the effects of poor management of
            Municipal Solid Waste (MSW). In 2008, Morocco produced about
            5 million tons of MSW per year and it is expected to reach
            6.2 million in 2020. The World Bank has been supporting
            Morocco’s efforts to improve economic, environmental, and
            social performance of MSW. The program has supported about
            80 municipalities to improve their collection services and
            upgrade their landfills. Private sector provided cleaning
            and garbage collection services to about 60 percent of the
            urban population compared to about 15 percent before the
            project. An innovative carbon finance program at the
            national level was designed to help local authorities
            mobilize additional financial resources. The program
            improved the reach and quality of solid waste collection
            services and contributed to the effort to mitigate climate
            change effects.
